intro: Chaerophyllum libanoticum, commonly known as the Lebanon cow-wheat, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, white or greenish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or dry soils and is adapted to temperate climates. It is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and forest edges. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
